description.narrative: Yemen Emergency crisis response funded by USAID to mitigate the impact of the current crisis on local households and communities and assist their recovery

participating-org.narrative: UNITED STATES AGENCY FOR INTERNATIONAL DEVELOPMENT (USAID)

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: - Level of income level of direct project beneficiaries (average income of the total beneficiaries; data: number of beneficiaries, female, IDPs/returnees, youth) - Number of people provided with access to basic services - Percentage of (monetary equivalent) benefits from temporary employment/ productive livelihoods options in the context of early economic recovery programmes received by women and girls

comment.narrative: - 0% Percentage of fishermen and farmers with increased capacities for productivity (skills, technologies) - 70 points extent to which the quality of coffee produce has increased. - 0 % Percentage of coffee and crop farmers/fishers supported who have adopted improved practices and technologies. - 0 Number of teachers (grade 4 - 12) received training on Interactive Learning Manual (disaggregated by gender). - 0 Number of teachers (grade 1-3) received training on Early Grade Reading and writing approach. (disaggregated by gender). -0 Number of students received Recreational Kit (disaggregated by gender) - materials related to psycho-social educational support - 0 Number of teachers, social workers and administrative staff trained on psychosocial support, social peace and conflict management, (disaggregated by gender) - 0 Number of students benefiting from psychosocial support, disaggregated by gender. - 0 Number of direct beneficiaries who received 20- day certification course on health care delivery as community mid-wives with start-up medical kits. - 0 Number of direct beneficiaries received 18-day training course on primary health care services as paramedic/primary health workers with medical kits (disaggregated by female, male) - 0 Number of health management staff and cadres received long-term health management training courses as direct beneficiary (disaggregated by female, male) - 0 Number of Physicians' assistants trained on internal and surgical diagnosis skills. - 0 Number of nurses and midwives trained on Premature and neonatal care services - 0 Number of high school graduated enrolled in health diploma courses and completed as qualified health cadre and staff. - 0 % of satisfaction of communities on the quality of health care received by trained mid-wives and paramedics - 0 Number of health consultants received training on consultancy and business planning for SMEs to build their capacities to become specialist consultants on private health sector. -

# Women and youth have enhanced skills to be employed in education:-
1. 2050 teachers (basic & secondary teachers) received technical teachers' training to improve the skills of practicing teachers employed in education. 2. 7500 students benefiting from improved teaching skills, disaggregated by girls and boys 3. 47,500 students benefited from recreational kits arts and reading materials enhancing reading, writing and numeracy skills for students grades 1-3
# Community mid-wives and paramedics have enhanced capacities to provide good quality private health services: 1. 193 direct beneficiaries who received 20- day certification course on health care delivery as community mid-wives with (Midwifery Kit) start-up medical kits along with income support (dis-aggregated by female, male); 18-day training on IMCI
# SMEs engaged in private health care provision effectively respond to health service needs : - 1. 30 SMEs consultants, received ( training in business Edge / Business plans & consultancy) to strengthen their capacities to provider business plans & consultancy to the beneficiaries 2.10 staff from lead-firm such as dental labs & medical industries received training on business continuity 3. 329 SMEs owned by business women such as mid-wives, doctors , pharmacies and etc. received technical support ( consultancy in business planning and management ) to strengthen their capacities to become resilient private health care providers. 4. 329 SMEs owned by business women such as mid-wives, doctors , pharmacies and etc. received (finical grants ) resilient private health care providers.
# Fishermen, coffee and crop farmers are enabled to expand their production through the development of the value chain, usage of modern inputs and improved practices: 1. 100 fishermen who participated in technical training programme and benefited from the project direct support 2. 200 farmers gained knowledge on solar energy and participated in technical training programme and benefited from project direct support 3. 165 fishermen and farmers received grants to support the sustainability of their business 4. External Capacity building in coffee sector for 1 Coffee Association and Internship for 20 agronomists # Supported SMEs benefit from enhanced financial services provided by Microfinance Institutions (MFIs) : 1. 1 MFI received technical and grants support for on-lending operations 2. 350 clients received support from on-lending operations by supported MFIs 3. 6 MFIs received in kind grants to strengthen security and client data protection systems 4. 3 new MFIs operational branches/outreach opened for rural financing and agriculture products

# Women and youth have enhanced skills to be employed in education 1. 2036 teachers Number of direct beneficiaries (basic & secondary teachers) received technical teachers' training to improve the skills of practicing teachers and employed in education. 2. 9590 students benefiting from improved teaching skills, disaggregated by girls and boys 3. 51,792 students benefited from recreational kits, arts and reading materials enhancing reading, writing and numeracy skills for students grades 1-3
#Community mid-wives and paramedics have enhanced capacities to provide good quality private health services 1. 445 direct beneficiaries have received 20- day certification course on health care delivery as community mid-wives with (Midwifery Kit) start-up medical kits along with income support 18-day training on IMCI # SMEs engaged in private health care provision effectively respond to health service needs : 1. 38 SMEs consultants have received ( training in business Edge / Business plans & consultancy) to strengthen their capacities to provider business plans & consultancy to the beneficiaries 2. 19 staff from lead-firm such as dental labs & medical industries have received training on business continuity 3. 329 SMEs owned by business women such as mid-wives, doctors , pharmacies and etc. received support ( consultancy in business planning and management ) to strengthen their capacities to become resilient private health care providers. 4. 282 SMEs owned by business women such as mid-wives, doctors , pharmacies and etc. received (finical grants ) resilient private health care providers. Fishermen, coffee and crop farmers are enabled to expand their production through the development of the value chain, usage of modern inputs and improved practices 1. 192 fishermen have participated in technical training programme and benefited from project direct support 2. 499 farmers gained knowledge on solar energy and participated technical training programme and benefited from the project direct support 3. 319 fishermen and farmers received grants to support the sustainability of their businesses This activity will be implemented in quarter three. External Capacity building in coffee sector for 1 Coffee Association and Internship for 20 agronomists Supported SMEs benefit from enhanced financial services provided by Microfinance Institutions (MFIs 1. 1 MFI received technical and grants support for on-lending operations 2. 513 clients received support from on-lending operations by supported MFIs 3. 0 MFIs received in kind grants to strengthen security and client data protection systems 4. 4 new MFIs operational branches/outreach have opened for rural financing and agriculture products
- Final Evaluation conducted. - End of project report prepared.
- Final Evaluation prepared and submitted to the donor. - End of project report prepared and submitted to donor.
